tossups.question: In a painting from this country, the hair of four insanely creepy women form the title object, The Wave. An artist from this home of Carlos Schwabe painted an old African man in Senecio. An artist from here painted a woman snubbing a necklace in favor of a boy with a scroll and his brother. (*) An artist from this country painted a rowboat going to the cypress-lined Isle of the Dead, and another artist from here painted a horse’s head poking into a bedroom. For 10 points, name this home of Arnold Bocklin, Paul Klee, Henry Fuseli, and Angelica Kauffmann.
tossups.answer: Switzerland [also accept any name that involves the term Swiss or the Helvetic Republic; prompt on England or Great Britain and equivalents with “where were they originally from?” on account of Kauffmann and Fuseli] <JG>
tossups.answer_formatted: Switzerland [also accept any name that involves the term Swiss or the Helvetic Republic; prompt on England or Great Britain and equivalents with “where were they originally from?” on account of Kauffmann and Fuseli]
promptable: Great Britain and equivalents with “where were they originally from?” on account of Kauffmann and Fuseli

tossups.question: A 1959 cover of The Australian Woman’s Weekly featured a member of this group sleeping. During a yuletide celebration, a member of this group inflicted flesh wounds to Max, and another once attacked a clockwinder. In 1999, this group’s food was spiked with whiskey and gin by a (*) footman. Three members of this group appeared alongside Daniel Craig at the 2012 Olympic opening ceremony, many of whom were cared for by Bill Fenwick, the groundskeeper at Sandringham. For 10 points, Susan was the first member of this group, the beloved canine companions to a certain monarch.
tossups.answer: Elizabeth II’s corgis [accept the Queen’s corgis; prompt on dogs; do not accept ‘dorgis’ or ‘cocker spaniels’] <LC>
tossups.answer_formatted: Elizabeth II’s corgis [accept the Queen’s corgis; prompt on dogs; do not accept "‘dorgis’" or "‘cocker spaniels’"]

tossups.question: Jens Ludwig and Bernard Harcourt used data from the Moving to Opportunity project to criticize a theory named for these things. The idiot son of “James Goodfellow” is central to the explanation of a fallacy named for these objects created by Frédéric Bastiat. Bill Bratton and Rudy Giuliani promoted (*) a policy named for these things first proposed in an article by James Wilson and George Kelling positing that zero tolerance of minor crimes will prevent worse ones. For 10 points, name these objects created by vandals, reversing the work of glaziers.
tossups.answer: Broken windows [prompt on windows; prompt on broken things; prompt on destruction] <HO>
tossups.answer_formatted: Broken windows [prompt on windows; prompt on broken things; prompt on destruction]

tossups.question: In early 2018, the anomalous magnetic moment of these particles was suggested to be the result of spacetime curvature from the Earth's gravitational field. One proposed method of reducing the energetic barrier to nuclear fusion is to form a (*) hydrogen analogue containing one of these particles. They are produced in the upper atmosphere by the decay of pions and, although unstable some are able to reach the earth's surface without decaying in an example of time dilation as confirmed in the Rossi-Hall experiment. For 10 points, name this second generation lepton with charge of -1.
tossups.answer: Muon (Prompt on “mu meson” with a reminder that this is no longer the preferred term for these particles, which are not mesons.) <YY>
tossups.metadata: Prompt on “mu meson” with a reminder that this is no longer the preferred term for these particles, which are not mesons.

tossups.question: Damage to these cells can be indicated by the Babinski sign. Granules of rough endoplasmic reticulum in these cells are stained by aniline in the Nissl stain. Astrocytes have numerous projections which link these cells to their blood supply. Mutations in proteins in these cells can cause (*) Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. Schwann cells coat part of these cells in a myelin sheath whose gaps allow for saltatory conduction. For 10 points, name these cells which contain long axons and conduct impulses in the nervous system.
tossups.answer: Neurons(or nerve cells)

tossups.question: In one film, this actress claims Arthur Hoggett will not eat a babe as Fly, and as Queen Oofeefa this actress says “stuff your nibbles” to Lord Nooth. It’s not Joanna Lumley, but in one film a boy opens an oven to find this actress’s character has prepared him a supper of baked (*) fish heads. This actress plays an Italian nurse in another film, who embraces her mistress at a wedding presided over by Pete Postlethwaite’s friar. In another role, this actress helps revive petrified students, having already warned a class about the potentially fatal scream of mandrakes. For 10 points, name this actress who portrayed Professor Sprout in the Harry Potter series.
tossups.answer: Miriam Margolyes <LC>

tossups.question: None of these bodies claim a specific foundation date, as custom is for them not to claim they are older than any other. Two of these institutions describe themselves as liberties and not governed by the City of London corporation. These bodies are governed by their senior members, who are known as (*) “benchers”. These institutions gradually became separated from the now-defunct Inns of Chancery. Lincoln’s Inn, Gray’s Inn, Middle Temple and Inner Temple are, for 10 points, what professional associations for barristers in England and Wales?
tossups.answer: Inns of Court <EM>

tossups.question: A schismatic plural bishop excommunicated by five successive popes supported the arm of this event's central figure. William of Poitiers recounted how an armed guard misinterpreted shouts of acclamation by this event’s crowd and set fire to some nearby buildings. (*) Ealdred of York presided over this event, which occurred on Christmas Day, and was followed two years later by a similar event recognising Matilda of Flanders as the English queen. For 10 points, name this event at which England's first Norman monarch received his crown.
tossups.answer: the coronation of William the Conqueror [or the coronation of William I; or the coronation of William the Bastard; accept crowning ceremony or equivalent in place of coronation] <HO>
tossups.answer_formatted: the coronation of William the Conqueror [or the coronation of William I; or the coronation of William the Bastard; accept crowning ceremony or equivalent in place of coronation]
acceptable: the coronation of William the Conqueror

tossups.question: John Wansbrough catalyzed contemporary critical study of this text’s composition. Theodor Noldëke devised the main chronology of this work’s composition from outside its tradition. The last two sections of this work are called “the Refuges” as they tell the reader, “Say: I seek (*) refuge in the Lord of Daybreak” and in “The Lord of Mankind.” This text describes humanity’s creation from a blood clot in a section revealed on the “Night of Power” when its author was commanded, “Recite!” For 10 points, name this text, revealed by the angel Jibrīl to Muḥammad.
tossups.answer: the Qur’ān <JG>

tossups.question: In one location of this type, Westmoreland asks the Archbishop “wherefore do you so ill translate yourself out of the speech of peace?” in Henry IV Part II. In another play, characters who live in one of these locations are said to “fleet the time carelessly as they did in the golden world” with the character of Duke (*) Senior. In another location of this type, a dispute over an Indian Boy leads Oberon to make Titania fall in love with the donkey-headed Bottom. For 10 points, name these natural locations such as Arden, which are central to the plots of As You Like It and A Midsummer Night’s Dream.
tossups.answer: Forests [accept woods or other clear knowledge equivalents] <Theo>

tossups.question: An eight-year-old polio victim’s experience of this event is described in the novel Ice-Candy Man. In a short story about this event, a father asks eight young men to find his daughter Sakina, who has lost her dupatta. The protagonist of a novel about this event is abandoned by his sister, The Brass Monkey, and (*) loses a special ability after having sinus surgery. In that novel, the exact moment of this event coincides with the birth of Shiva of the Knees and Saleem Sinai. For 10 points, name this 1947 event, which creates a group of Midnight’s Children.
tossups.answer: partition [accept the division of India; accept the creation of Pakistan or equivalents; accept the independence of India; accept the independence of Pakistan] <HO>
tossups.answer_formatted: partition [accept the division of India; accept the creation of Pakistan accept equivalents; accept the independence of India; accept the independence of Pakistan]

tossups.question: One official who called this ruler a usurper had his kin uniquely exterminated to the tenth degree. This emperor wiped out much of the Ho dynasty to begin the Fourth Chinese Domination of Vietnam and seized power in the Jingnan Campaign. Only 3.5 percent of this (*) emperor’s gigantic namesake encyclopedia edited by Yao Guangxiao survives, and this builder of the Porcelain Tower allegedly sought the nephew whose throne he seized by dispatching Zheng He on his voyages. For 10 points, name this third Ming emperor, who moved his capital to Beijing and began the construction of the Forbidden City.
tossups.answer: Zhu Di [Accept Yongle Emperor, Chengzu Emperor of Ming, or Taizong Emperor of Ming. Prompt on Prince of Yan] <YY>
tossups.answer_formatted: Zhu Di [Accept Yongle Emperor, Chengzu Emperor of Ming, or Taizong Emperor of Ming. Prompt on Prince of Yan]

tossups.question: Ada Lovelace and Phyllis Pearsall provided the inspiration for names of machines used in this project. During this project, the nickname “the eye of the needle” was given to a location where a tunnel had to be bored between two existing tunnels with less than a metre clearance on each side. The British (*) Rail Class 345 began service in 2017 on the first part of this project, which opened under the name “TfL Rail” . Eventually running from Reading to Shenfield, for 10 points, name this project which will fully open in 2019 as the Elizabeth Line.
tossups.answer: Crossrail (accept the Elizabeth Line before mention)
tossups.metadata: accept the Elizabeth Line before mention

tossups.question: Diogenes Laertius claims that this thinker privileged the two elements of earth and fire, though this is not apparent in a poem in which he criticised the binary of “what is” and “what is not”, which he called a product of the “Way of Opinion”. He opposes this (*) to the Way of Truth. This thinker presents the “third man” argument against Plato’s forms in a namesake dialogue. This thinker’s student illustrated this thinker’s idea that change is impossible with a set of paradoxes. For 10 points, name this thinker, the founder of the Eleatic school.
tossups.answer: Parmenides <CB>

tossups.question: Observations of a nebula in this constellation led William Herschel to declare that “the nebulosity about the star is not of a starry nature”. This constellation is the location of the namesake of a class of variable pre-main-sequence stars discovered by John Russell Hind. The northwest part of this constellation contains the supernova remnant (*) M1, commonly known as the Crab Nebula. This constellation is home to two of the nearest open clusters to Earth: the Pleiades and the Hyades. For 10 points identify this constellation of the zodiac, home to the red giant Aldebaran, whose name comes from the Latin for “bull”.
tossups.answer: Taurus <MN>

tossups.question: Hearing the word “yalla” in a film prompted Ray Hanania to write about Arabs affected by this event. Steiff produced 600 black “mourning teddies” after this event. William Alden Smith led a Senate enquiry into this event, which might have been prevented had David Blair not accidentally taken the key to a binoculars storage cupboard. Robert Ballard (*) discovered the remains of this event in 1985, and its survivors included Molly Brown, who was rescued by the RMS Carpathia. For 10 points, identify this 1912 event in which a passenger liner collided with an iceberg.
tossups.answer: sinking of the RMS Titanic [accept equivalents] <EJW>
tossups.answer_formatted: sinking of the RMS Titanic [ accept equivalents]

tossups.question: In this novel, one character tells a story about an old woman whose guardian angel attempts to pull her out of hell with an onion. Another symbol in this novel, a “galloping” three-horse carriage, stands for the country careening out of control. In this novel, a man is convicted of murdering his father with a brass pestle, and the (*) dead priest Father Zosima’s holiness is doubted when his corpse stinks quickly. Two characters served by Smerdyakov fight over Grushenka and the fable of the Grand Inquisitor is told in, for 10 points, which novel about Dmitri, Ivan, and Alyosha by Fyodor Dostoyevsky?
tossups.answer: The Brothers Karamazov <SR>

tossups.question: This compound is the starting point for preparation of the chiral auxiliary SAMP. The CBS catalyst is derived from the reaction of borane with this compound. A key early result in chiral organocatalysis was the discovery of the HPESW reaction, an asymmetric aldol catalysed by this compound. A polymer of this compound and its (*) hydroxy- derivative is the primary secondary structure in collagen. It contains a secondary amine as part of its pyrrolidine side-chain. For 10 points, name this amino acid abbreviated “Pro”.
tossups.answer: Proline (accept P) <EM> NOTE TO MODERATOR: Emphasise “recreated” in the first line.

tossups.question: A triptych using this artistic material recreated a painting depicting the suicide of George Dyer. A work of this material allegedly plagiarised This is My Body, This is My Blood by John LeKay, while Mark Bridger used black ink to vandalise another work of this material. Another work using this material may have degraded due to the addition of bleach by the (*) Saatchi Gallery, and has been dubbed “£50,000 Fish without Chips”. A 2016 study claims this material is leaking carcinogenic gas out of four boxes containing a bisected calf and cow. For 10 points, name this artistic material employed by Damien Hirst, with the chemical formula CH2O.
tossups.answer: Formaldehyde solution [accept CH2O until read] <LC>

tossups.question: To incapacitate Humbaba, Shamash uses several of these weapons including one called shaparziqqu. Anu gives four of these weapons to Marduk upon the latter’s birth, and Marduk forced one called the imhullu down an enemy’s throat to (*) “distend” Tiamat’s belly before splitting her in half with an arrow. A god of this phenomenon used a talking mace to talk to his son Ninurta and used a series of disguises to seduce Ninlil. For 10 points, name this natural force associated with Enlil and personified in Greece by Boreas and Zephyr.
tossups.answer: Winds [also accept any type of wind; also accept answers like storms or tempests after “arrow”] <JG>
tossups.answer_formatted: Winds [also accept any type of wind; also accept answers like storms or tempests after “arrow”]

tossups.question: A letter A, a bottom segment of the globe, and a pair of hands appear on a background of this colour in Whitney Smith’s proposed flag of Antarctica. A flag which contains a background of yellow and this colour depicts Druk holding four (*) jewels. A river named for this colour is known as the Senqu for part of its reach. Water from that river is diverted from the Gariep Dam to the Fish River by a tunnel. For 10 points, name this colour that links a river whose tributaries include the Vaal, and the ruling house of the Netherlands.
tossups.answer: Orange <EM>

tossups.question: One poem about this person asks “what fires run, what craving wakes?” within them, and describes this person as a “panther” following the poet. In another poem, this person is equated with the figure of Kindness who hands the poet (*) “two children, two roses”. Another poem implies that this person was “the vampire who said he was you and drank my blood”; that poem appears in a collection put together by this man in 1965. For 10 points, name this man with a “Meinkampf look” who responded to works like “Daddy” with his own collection Birthday Letters, the poet husband of Sylvia Plath.
tossups.answer: Ted Hughes <JK>

tossups.question: He’s not Handel, but movements titled “The Joking Triton” and “The Merry Boat People” are included in this composer’s Water Music. In an opera by this composer, Vespetta takes advantage of her marriage to the title character, Pimpinone. This composer was succeeded in his post as music director for (*) Hamburg’s five largest churches by his godson, C. P. E. Bach. One piece by this composer consists of three “productions” and was intended to be performed as accompaniment to a meal. For 10 points, identify this prolific Baroque composer who wrote Musique de Table, or Tafelmusik.
tossups.answer: Georg Philipp Telemann <MN>

tossups.question: Legend has it that five stars appeared over the death of a saint tossed off a bridge in this city when that saint refused to tell the king what the queen said in confession. Ottokar the Golden is buried in this city. The main university of this city, where John of Nepomuk died, was founded by and named for (*) Charles IV. A dean of that university in this city translated John Wycliffe and was condemned and burned at Constance. The St.Vitus Cathedral in this city houses the crown of St Wenceslas, and Jan Hus began his preaching in this city. For 10 points name this city, the capital of Bohemia.
tossups.answer: Prague [or Praha] <JS> Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: In 1993, one of the countries which claims this figure as a spiritual ancestor made the somewhat bold claim that they had found his tomb, and that his pubic bone was tremendously large. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this mythological figure. His mother was originally a bear, whose prayer to become a woman was answered after she retreated to a cave with a tiger and ate only garlic and mugwort for a hundred days.

Dangun is the legendary founder of Gojoseon, the first kingdom to rule this peninsula. One of his first acts was to build the walled city of Asadal, which may have been located near modern-day Pyongyang.

A Korean superstition against harming these animals derives from the fact that the wealth goddess Eopsin often takes this form. In Chinese myth, Fuxi and Nuwa are often depicted as this animal from the waist down.

bonuses.leadin: The appearance of these figures at the end of Return of the King is often cited as an egregious example of a deus ex machina by readers who didn’t realise that the story was about the journey, not the destination. For 10 points each:
parts: In Tolkien’s work, this race of birds always seems to turn up exactly when needed, be it to rescue Gandalf from Orthanc, defeat the Orcs attacking the Lonely Mountain or stop Morgoth crushing Fingolfin’s body.
This is the mightiest of the Eagles in The Lord of the Rings, and also the presumed King of the Eagles in The Hobbit. This eagle mainly acts as Gandalf’s personal taxi service.
This is the original leader of the Eagles in The Silmarillion. It has a wingspan of 30 fathoms, or 180 feet.

bonuses.leadin: After it was revealed that Michelle Williams received just $800 for reshoots of All the Money in the World, Mark Wahlberg donated his $1.5 million pay cheque to this movement. For 10 points each:
parts: Kevin Spacey was edited out of that film after sexual allegations were made against him, inspiring the set-up of this movement in January 2018. It asks Weinstein Effect victims to speak out using the hashtag “MeToo”.
Members of Hollywood attending this ceremony on 7 January wore black in solidarity with Time’s Up. This event saw Oprah Winfrey address the movement in her Cecil B. DeMille Award acceptance speech.

In the aftermath of the Golden Globes, Aziz Ansari was accused of sexual misconduct in an exposé on this website aimed at young women, proving that wearing black means very little if one has no idea what consent is to start with.

bonuses.leadin: This couple are obliquely mentioned in Kurt Vonnegut’s Breakfast of Champions, during a post-coital discussion of the electric chair. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American couple executed for spying for the USSR in 1953. The opening line of The Bell Jar refers to a “queer, sultry summer, the year they electrocuted [this couple]”.

The ghost of Ethel Rosenberg appears several times in this play, judging the lawyer Roy Cohn for hoarding AZT drugs and later praying a kaddish for Cohn alongside Prior Walter’s ex-boyfriend Louis Ironson.

The Rosenbergs are also fictionalised as “Paul and Rochelle Isaacson” in The Book of Daniel, by this author. This author wrote about mobsters Otto Berman and Dutch Schultz mentoring the title child in Billy Bathgate.

bonuses.leadin: This piece’s second movement Allegro Molto scherzando is based on a seguidilla, and it opens with a dramatic D minor habanera. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this five movement piece, written for Pablo de Sarasate, which, despite its name, is actually a violin concerto.
Symphonie Espagnole is the best known work of this French Romantic composer - also known for his G Minor final symphony, and his opera Le Roi d’Ys.
Hearing Symphonie Espagnole for the first time inspired this Russian composer to write his Violin Concerto in D Major. This composer also wrote the 1812 Overture and ballets such as Swan Lake.

bonuses.leadin: John von Neumann, aside from changing the face of pretty much every scientific field, had a colossal impact on early computer science. For 10 points each, answer some questions about it.
parts: Von Neumann introduced this method of algorithmically generating pseudo-random numbers. Though computationally easy, its short period of at most 8^n for n-digit numbers means that it is now rarely used.

A more lasting contribution was his description of the Von Neumann architecture for computers. In its simplest form, the CPU communicates with this kind of unit. This concept has types such as random-access and read-only.

With Stanislaw Ulam, von Neumann introduced this computational model. They consist of infinite grids of entities with various states, which evolve each generation according to certain rules, and include Conway’s Game of Life.

bonuses.leadin: The Africana existentialist Lewis Gordon advocates doing this action to “disciplinarity,” i.e. to philosophy itself, to recover a sense of the fundamental reasons for doing philosophy at all. For 10 points each:
answers: teleologically suspend something [also accept word forms and answers with the ethical as a direct object; prompt on answers like sacrifice someone or sacrifice one’s child]
Fear and Trembling [or Frygt og Baeven]
parts: Name this action, whose original formulator contrasts the decisions of Agamemnon, Jephthah, and Brutus with those of a man who did this specific intellectual action and thus got back something “by virtue of the absurd.”

“Is there a Teleological Suspension of the Ethical?” constitutes Problema 1 of this work, which examines Abraham’s sacrifice of Isaac to describe the progression from “infinite resignation” to the “knight of faith.”
Fear and Trembling is a work by this Danish philosopher, the author of Either/Or and The Sickness Unto Death and the dumper of Regine Olsen.
answers_formatted: teleologically suspend something [also accept word forms and answers with the ethical as a direct object; prompt on answers like sacrifice someone or sacrifice one’s child]

bonuses.leadin: The small towns of Bizen and Koka still produce traditional examples of this art form, exhibiting “goma” and “hidasuki” patterns. For 10 points each:
answers: pottery [accept ceramics or earthenware or clear equivalents]
tea ceremony [accept anything that mentions tea, accept cha no yu, accept chado]
Sen no Rikyu [accept Yoshiro Yohei, accept Soeki]
parts: Name this art form of masters like Manji Inoue. Works in this form from the Kofun period can be split into “hagi” and “sue” [SOO-AY] styles, while the Jomon period was known for “cord-marked” examples.
A lot of Japanese pottery made during the Edo period was used for this ritual purpose. Those who perform this ritual may drink sencha or, more commonly, matcha.
This greatest tea master of all time developed the wabi-sabi aesthetic of the tea ceremony, and served under both Oda Nobunaga and Toyotomi Hideyoshi, though the latter forced him to commit suicide.
answers_formatted: tea ceremony [accept anything that mentions tea, or cha no yu, or chado]

bonuses.leadin: Apart from humans, these insects form the most complex animal societies on Earth, and their nests can grow to more than 30 metres across. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these ants belonging to the genera Atta and Acromyrmex which cultivate fungus by feeding it fresh vegetation.They can carry more twenty times their body weight.
This term describes a symbiotic relationship that is beneficial to both parties, such as that between leaf cutter ants and their fungi.
The ants feed on these swellings on the hyphae of their cultivated fungus.

bonuses.leadin: Members of this cult would carry only a five-dollar bill and a roll of quarters when in public. For 10 points each:
answers: The appearance of a comet [or specifically, the appearance of Hale-Bopp/Great Comet of 1997/ C/1995 O1; accept any description that remotely gets this across; prompt on but DO NOT OTHERWISE REVEAL a UFO appearing with “what did non-cult members see the “UFO” as?”]
parts: Name this cult, which was led by Marshall Applewhite and Bonnie Nettles, professed that the Earth was soon to be ‘recycled’, and whose members sought to ascend to The Evolutionary Level Above Human.
The Heaven’s Gate cult remains best known for an act of mass suicide committed during one of these events.
Members of Heaven’s Gate believed that one of these objects was trailing the Comet Hale-Bopp. Raëlism is a religion closely associated with these objects.
answers_formatted: The appearance of a comet [or specifically, the appearance of Hale-Bopp/Great Comet of 1997/ C/1995 O1; accept any description that remotely gets this across; prompt on but DO NOT OTHERWISE REVEAL a UFO appearing with “what did non-cult members see the “UFO” as?”]
acceptable: specifically, the appearance of Hale-Bopp/Great Comet of 1997/ C/1995 O1
any description that remotely gets this across
promptable: but DO NOT OTHERWISE REVEAL a UFO appearing with “what did non-cult members see the “UFO” as?”

bonuses.leadin: In one scene in this novel, the protagonist shoves a copy of Corinne down the throat of a wolf trying to attack him and Anna in their sledge. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel. In this work, Margareta Samzelius rescues the title priest who has been defrocked for alcoholism and brings him to her manor, Ekeby, where he leads a band of twelve cavaliers into various hijinks.
Gösta Berling’s Saga was the debut novel by this Swedish author who went on to write The Wonderful Adventures of Nils, and won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1909.

A more rogue work by Lagerlöf is Thy Soul Shall Bear Witness!, a novel teaching the reader how to avoid this disease. Helen Burns dies of this disease in Jane Eyre, after spending several chapters ominously coughing up blood.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about nativism and anti-immigrant sentiment in nineteenth-century America, for 10 points each:
answers: The Know-Nothing Party [also accept the deeply ironic early name of The Native American Party]
Roman Catholics [also accept Papists or Romanists from actual Know-Nothings]
parts: Levi Boone banned immigrants from all jobs upon becoming mayor of Chicago on this party’s ticket. Officially the American Party, its unofficial name came from members’ response to questions about membership.
The Know-Nothings were most opposed to immigrants of this religion, who were mainly from Germany and Ireland at the time, as they believed it to be organizing a plot to subvert civil liberties.

This city was the site of a 1856 riot by pro-Know-Nothing gangs like the Plug Uglies and Bloody Tubs over its mayoral race. This city’s 1861 Pratt Street Riot wrecked a German-owned newspaper called “the Wrecker.”
answers_formatted: The Know-Nothing Party [also accept the deeply ironic early name of The Native American Party]
Roman Catholics [also accept Papists or Romanists from actual Know-Nothings]

bonuses.leadin: This work’s author never publicly admitted to writing it, using the pseudonym Conny Keyber to publish it. For 10 points each:
answers: An Apology for the Life of Mrs. Shamela Andrews
parts: Name this novel in which it is revealed that the title character is a cunning former prostitute, manipulating Squire Booby into falling for her so she can steal his fortune - and telling us all of this in epistolary fashion.

Shamela was Henry Fielding’s parody of this author’s novel Pamela. This author described his title heroine enduring continual harassment from her boss Mr. B, and having her “virtue rewarded” by marrying him.

This novel is also sometimes considered a response to Pamela, due to its subtitle “The Misfortunes of Virtue”. In this novel, Thérèse tells her scandalous life story to Madame de Lorsagne before getting struck by lightning.
answers_formatted: An Apology for the Life of Mrs. Shamela Andrews
acceptable: An Apology for the Life of Mrs. Shamela Andrews

bonuses.leadin: An early prank played by members of this group involved pretending to be the Sultan of Zanzibar on a state visit to Cambridge. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this collection of English writers and intellectuals which included Adrian Stephen and Virginia Woolf.

Virginia Woolf went with Horace de Vere Cole performed a similar prank on this Royal Navy ship, where they blacked up and dressed in turbans pretending to be a delegation from the royal family of Abyssinia.

While pretending to be the Abyssinian, the group repeatedly expressed their amazement with this phrase. This phrase has since been used to describe the wild sex parties of former Italian PM Silvio Berlusconi.

bonuses.leadin: The L-form of this amino acid is converted into nitric oxide by endothelial nitric oxide synthase. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this amino acid, which is hydrolysed by a namesake enzyme to form ornithine.
The hydrolysis of arginine to form ornithine occurs with the release of this molecule, which names a cycle discovered by Hans Krebs, in which the namesake molecule is produced from ammonia.
The urea cycle consists of four reactions. Three occur in the cytoplasm; the other occurs in this organelle, often known as the powerhouse of the cell.

bonuses.leadin: A “General History” of these people by the mysterious Charles Johnson includes an epic speech in which one declares himself a “free prince” with “authority to make war on the whole world.” For 10 points each:
answers: pirates [also accept corsairs; anti-prompt on privateers]
Captain Samuel “Black Sam” Bellamy (Charles Johnson has him give the speech in the lead-in to the original captain of the Whydah Galley) <JG>
parts: Name these people, some of whom received letters of marque. Japanese ones were called “wokou” or “dwarf bandits,” and the Barbary coast became a notorious enclave for ones like the operators of the Salé Republic.
Charles Johnson described a likely fictional anarchist pirate utopia called Libertalia in what is now this country. This country’s Merina kingdom was subjected to France after the Franco-Hova wars.
This “Prince of Pirates” and, like Blackbeard, alumnus of Benjamin Hornigold’s crew, became spectacularly wealthy after capturing the Whydah Galley, but died at 28 in a storm off Cape Cod.
metadata: Charles Johnson has him give the speech in the lead-in to the original captain of the Whydah Galley

bonuses.leadin: This historian examined disputes related to the use of forests and chases in a work which argued that the 1723 Black Act was the product of an emergent, oppressive, market-oriented regime. For 10 points each:
answers: “The Moral Economy of the English Crowd”
bread [accept, flour, grain, specific grains such as wheat, or just food in general] <HO>
parts: Name this Marxist historian, best known for his study The Making of the English Working Class.
In a 1971 Past and Present article, Thompson considered this title facet of the English crowd in the eighteenth century. The setting of “fair prices” by riotous peasants was central to this concept.

Thompson's article considered riots and the sending of threatening letters prompted by scarcity of this stuff and its export to cities. Word of this commodity’s scarcity prompted Marie Antoinette’s most infamous remark.
answers_formatted: “The Moral Economy of the English Crowd”
bread [accept accept, flour, grain, specific grains such as wheat, or just food in general]
acceptable: “The Moral Economy of the English Crowd”
accept, flour, grain, specific grains such as wheat,

bonuses.leadin: Testa and Reinmuth proposed notation for reactions of this type. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these reactions which rely on an electric current. Performing one of these reactions on brine is the basis of the chlor-alkali process.
The mechanisms of electrolysis reactions can be studied with this technique, where the potential difference is increased, the current measured, and the voltage swept back down again.

Electrochemists massively overuse this substance. An early hydrodynamic electrode relied on dripping this substance down a fine capillary, and a layer of it formed the cathode in the Castner-Kellner process for brine electrolysis.

bonuses.leadin: The movement of atoms from one quantum state is a staple of experimental quantum physics. For 10 points:
parts: Name these constraints which are placed upon the allowed transitions. One of these statements notes that parity must change by plus or minus one and is named for Laporte.

This eponymous formula described the rate of transition under a weak, time-dependent perturbation as being proportional to the modulus squared of the matrix element of the perturbing Hamiltonian between final and initial states.
These devices produce monochromatic electromagnetic radiation by stimulated emissions of atoms of an active medium which have undergone population inversion.

bonuses.leadin: Artists, for some reason, aren’t always that well-balanced. Answer some questions about ones who moonlighted as murderers, for 10 points each:
answers: Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio [accept either underlined portion]
Andrea del Castagno [also accept Andrea di Bartolo di Bargilla] <JK>
parts: Perhaps the best-known artsy manslayer is this Baroque painter, who killed a man allegedly after a tennis game. He pioneered tenebrism in works like David with the Head of Goliath and The Calling of St Matthew.

This Mannerist goldsmith stabbed the arquebusier who had killed his brother, and claimed to have killed thirty more with an artillery blast during the Sack of Rome. His non-deadly output includes the Salt Cellar of Francis I.

Vasari claimed that this artist murdered Domenico Veneziano to keep the secret of oil painting, even though he died before Veneziano. He definitely painted a fresco of Niccolo da Tolentino in Florence Cathedral, though.
answers_formatted: Andrea del Castagno [also accept Andrea di Bartolo di Bargilla]

bonuses.leadin: An encounter with this person while studying at Oxford inspired Godfrey Lienhardt to become an anthropologist himself. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this British anthropologist, whose works include Theories of Primitive Religion and Witchcraft, Oracles and Magic among the Azande. He trained under Bronislaw Malinowski and Charles Gabriel Seligman.

Evans-Pritchard conducted extensive studies on the Nu’er people of Sudan, analysing practices such as their “ghost” form of this practice. Cattle may be given as a dowry before one of these ceremonies.

Evans-Pritchard was also a proponent of the structural-functionalist view of social anthropology, the founder of which is often considered to be this man who studied the Andaman Islanders and tribes in Western Australia.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about attempts to shut down urban slums:
parts: Politician Azouz Begag described his childhood growing up in Chaâba [shabba], a “can town” in this European country dismantled during a 1960s clampdown. This country still has over 570 urban slums, home to Roma and refugees.

In 1994, the Hong Kong government demolished this densely populated housing complex near Kai Tak Airport, which had been home to brothels, opium dens, and triads like 14K and Sun Yee On. This complex is now a city park.

The run-up to the 2016 Olympics, meanwhile, featured controversial clearances of these settlements, which account for 6% of homes in Brazil. One of these settlements, Mangueira, is 750m from the Maracana stadium.

bonuses.leadin: Even after the French Wars of Religion, France was still not very happy on the religious front. For 10 points each, answer some questions on later French religious intransigence:
answers: Louis XIV [also accept Louis le Grand, Louis the Great, Le Roi Soleil, or the Sun King; prompt on Louis]
parts: To the plaudits of Antoine Arnauld, this king promulgated the pro-absolutist 1682 Declaration of the Clergy of France, causing a long feud with the Pope. This king revoked the Edict of Nantes and stated “l’état, c’est moi.”

The Declaration of the Clergy of France codified and promulgated this French anti-ultramontanist doctrine championed by Pierre Pithou that holds that the Pope had spiritual, but not temporal, jurisdiction.

Louis particularly feuded with the 11th pope of this name, but had some détente with the 12th. The 3rd pope of this name fought King John over Stephen Langton, called the Fourth Lateran Council, and launched the Fourth Crusade.
answers_formatted: Louis XIV [also accept Louis le Grand, Louis the Great, Le Roi Soleil, or the Sun King; prompt on Louis]

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of this novel sees himself as Othello and his wife as Desdemona, a theme echoed throughout with Shakespearean quotations. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel, whose title character Bento is plagued with jealousy over his wife Capitu’s suspected infidelity with his friend Escobar, and begins to doubt that Ezequiel is really his son.
Dom Casmurro is a novel by this author, who also penned Quincas Borba and The Posthumous Memoirs of Bras Cubas and has been called the “supreme black literary artist” by Harold Bloom.
Machado de Assis hailed from this South American nation. This country was the home of Jorge Amado and Clarice Lispector who, like Machado, wrote in Portuguese.
